Title: Architecture and connections of prefrontal cortex
Abstract:
An investigation of the architectonic organization and intrinsic connections of the prefrontal cortex was conducted in rhesus monkeys. Cytoarchitectonic analysis indicates that in the
prefrontal cortex there are two trends of gradual change in laminar characteristics that can be traced from limbic periallocortex towards isocortical areas. The stepwise change in laminar
features is characterized by the emergence and gradual increase in the width of granular layer IV, by an increase in the size of pyramidal cells in layers III and V, and by a higher
cell-packing density in the supragranular layers. Myeloarchitectonic analysis reveals that the limbic areas are poorly myelinated, adjacent areas have a diffuse myelin content confined to
the deep layers, and in isocortices the myelinated fibers are distributed in organized horizontal bands (of Bail-larger) and a vertical plexus. Using the above architectonic criteria, we
observed that one of the architectonic trends takes a radial basoventral course from the periallocortex in the caudal orbitofrontal region to the adjacent proisocortex and then to area 13.
The next stage of architectonic regions includes orbital areas 12, 11, and 14, which is followed by area 10, lateral area 12, and the rostral part of ventral area 46. The last group includes
the caudal part of ventral area 46 and ventral area 8. The other trend takes a mediodorsal course from the periallocortex around the rostral portion of the corpus callosum to the adjacent
proisocortical areas 24, 25, and 32 and then to the medially situated isocortical areas 9, 10, and 14. The next stage includes lateral areas 10 and 9 and the rostral part of dorsal area 46.
The last group includes the caudal part of dorsal area 46 and dorsal area 8. The interconnections of subdivisions of the basoventral and mediodorsal cortices were studied with the aid of
anterograde and retrograde tracers. Within each trend a given area projects in two directions: to adjoining regions belonging to succeeding architectonic stages on the one hand, and to
nearby regions from the preceding architectonic stage on the other. In each direction there is more than one region involved in this projection system, paralleling the radial nature of
architectonic change. Periallo- and proisocortices have widespread intrinsic connections, whereas isocortices situated at a distance from limbic areas, such as area 8, have restricted
connections. Most interconnections are limited to areas within the same architectonic trend. However, there are links between cortices from the two trends, and these seem to occur
between areas that are at a similar stage of architectonic differentiation.

@BrainMaps.Comments: It seems likely that this parcellation of prefrontal areas is at least similar, if not identical, to the parcellation of BP82 presented in abstract form. There is, however, no such reference given.

@BrainMaps_Delineation.Citation: "The architectonic classification of prefrontal areas that we have described in this study is in general agreement with the parcellation of Walker (1940). In fact, we have adhered to the numerical nomenclature of Walker. There are, however, some differences between our observations those of Walker." (p. 370)

"We have considered the cortex in the rostral bank of the upper and lower limbs of the arcuate sulcus and the adjacent rostral cortex as area 8, in agreement with the map of Brodmann (1905). Walker divided this region into a dorsal region (area 8) and a ventral region (area 45). We also observed a difference between the dorsal and the ventral vectors but we consider these regions as dorsal and ventral area 8 because of their basic similarity." (p. 370)

We also observed a difference between the dorsal and the ventral vectors but we consider these regions as dorsal and ventral area 8 because of their basic similarity." (p. 370)

"The architectonic classification of prefrontal areas that we have described in this study is in general agreement with the parcellation of Walker (1940). "The architectonic classification of prefrontal areas that we have described in this study is in general agreement with the parcellation of Walker (1940). In fact, we have adhered to the numerical nomenclature of Walker. There are, however, some differences between our observations and those of Walker ... On the medial surface, Walker designated a region rostral to 24 as 25. This area has been termed area 32 by Brodmann (1905), Pandya et al. (1981), and Vogt et al. (1987). Like these investigators, we also consider area 32 as a distinct region in front of area 24. In agreement with Vogt et al. (1987), area 25 occupies a position below the rostrum of the corpus callosum." (pp. 370-371)

@InterMapRelations.Comments: B05 does not delineate an area 32, this was done 4 years later in the revised map of B09. Also, the map of Brodmann shown in Fig. 1B is wrongly labelled as "Brodmann 1905"; in fact, this is Brodmann's later map published in 1909.

@Injections.Citation: "In case 1 an isotope injection was placed in the caudal orbital cortex and involved primarily the area we termed proisocortex and to a lesser extent the adjacent area 13"

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "Labeled grains in this case were observed in the adjacent portions of proisocortex and area 13. Additionally, label was found in area 14 medially, 12 laterally, and in areas 11 and 10 rostrally on the orbital surface. On the medial surface areas 25, 32, 14, and to a lesser extent area 9 also contained label. Moreover, in this case label was noted on the lateral surface in areas 12 and 10."
@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Comments: Laminar patterns of terminations were reported as pooled data only (pp. 367-368; Fig. 14) so that it was not possible to determine the laminar pattern of an individual projection.

@Injections.Citation: "In case 10 an isotope injection was placed in area 9 above the rostral part of the principal sulcusThe injection also involved the upper portion of the adjacent rostral area 46."
@Injections.Comments: Table 2, p. 371, mentions an area "D9", but according to p. 360 and the usage in the rest of the text area 9 is subdivided into M9 and L9. Therefore, "D9" is understood as being part of L9.

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "On the medial surface label was found in areas 32, 24, 9, and 10. Distinct clusters of labelled grains were observed on the lateral surface in the rostral portion of dorsal area 6 and 8 and in the rostral part of dorsal area 46 below the injection site. Small clusters of label were seen ventrally in area 12 and in the orbital portion of area 10."
@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Comments: Laminar patterns of terminations were reported as pooled data only (pp. 367-368; Fig. 14) so that it was not possible to determine the laminar pattern of an individual projection.

@Injections.Citation: "In case 11 an isotope injection was placed in dorsal area 10 at the frontal pole. There was, however, some invasion of medial and ventral area 10."

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "On the medial surface, label was found in areas 32, 24, 14, and 9. Label was observed also on the lateral surface in rostral areas 9 and 10 and the adjoining area 46. Small clusters of label were observed in lateral area 12 and in areas 12, 14, 11, and 10 on the orbital surface."
@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Comments: Laminar patterns of terminations were reported as pooled data only (pp. 367-368; Fig. 14) so that it was not possible to determine the laminar pattern of an individual projection.

@Injections.Citation: "In cases 12 and 13 isotope injections were placed in dorsal area 46. In case 12 the injection involved also a small part of area 9"

@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Citation: "Label was observed in rostral areas 24, 9, and 10and in area 32on the medial surface. On the lateral surface labeled grains were found rostral to the injection site in areas 10 and 9 and caudally in dorsal areas 46, 8 and 6."
@LabelledSites_Descriptions.Comments: Laminar patterns of terminations were reported as pooled data only (pp. 367-368; Fig. 14) so that it was not possible to determine the laminar pattern of an individual projection.

@Injections.Citation: "In cases 12 and 13 isotope injections were placed in dorsal area 46In case 13 the isotope involved the rostral part of dorsal 46 and slightly ventral area 46."

publication.title: Architecture and connections of prefrontal cortex
publication.abstract:
An investigation of the architectonic organization and intrinsic connections of the prefrontal cortex was conducted in rhesus monkeys. Cytoarchitectonic analysis indicates that in the
prefrontal cortex there are two trends of gradual change in laminar characteristics that can be traced from limbic periallocortex towards isocortical areas. The stepwise change in laminar
features is characterized by the emergence and gradual increase in the width of granular layer IV, by an increase in the size of pyramidal cells in layers III and V, and by a higher
cell-packing density in the supragranular layers. Myeloarchitectonic analysis reveals that the limbic areas are poorly myelinated, adjacent areas have a diffuse myelin content confined to
the deep layers, and in isocortices the myelinated fibers are distributed in organized horizontal bands (of Bail-larger) and a vertical plexus. Using the above architectonic criteria, we
observed that one of the architectonic trends takes a radial basoventral course from the periallocortex in the caudal orbitofrontal region to the adjacent proisocortex and then to area 13.
The next stage of architectonic regions includes orbital areas 12, 11, and 14, which is followed by area 10, lateral area 12, and the rostral part of ventral area 46. The last group includes
the caudal part of ventral area 46 and ventral area 8. The other trend takes a mediodorsal course from the periallocortex around the rostral portion of the corpus callosum to the adjacent
proisocortical areas 24, 25, and 32 and then to the medially situated isocortical areas 9, 10, and 14. The next stage includes lateral areas 10 and 9 and the rostral part of dorsal area 46.
The last group includes the caudal part of dorsal area 46 and dorsal area 8. The interconnections of subdivisions of the basoventral and mediodorsal cortices were studied with the aid of
anterograde and retrograde tracers. Within each trend a given area projects in two directions: to adjoining regions belonging to succeeding architectonic stages on the one hand, and to
nearby regions from the preceding architectonic stage on the other. In each direction there is more than one region involved in this projection system, paralleling the radial nature of
architectonic change. Periallo- and proisocortices have widespread intrinsic connections, whereas isocortices situated at a distance from limbic areas, such as area 8, have restricted
connections. Most interconnections are limited to areas within the same architectonic trend. However, there are links between cortices from the two trends, and these seem to occur
between areas that are at a similar stage of architectonic differentiation.
